item.title: Fake Virus
item.dc:creator: @pplsuqbawlz pplsuqbawlz
item.description:
@pplsuqbawlz wrote:

Lol thank you javac, i meant dimensions* and it’s 255 lol you’re right.

Mai bad, but in any case, the jvm is limited to it’s heap to prevent such abuse of programming; Or so i thought, isn’t the standard 64mb for applets and 128/256 for applications? I dunno -Xmx512mb = what I use in almost all of my proggies gg.

Edit: Wait, “You could then iterate through the array to make sure it pulls it off the disk as often as possible.” Writing and reading from a file? maybe, bug abusing on virtual memory(because of nastily coded operating systems/cheap computers?)? ^ read above short statement.

S > C

D2GS_LoadAct { BYTE id = 0x03; BYTE act; DWORD hash_upper;' WORD psbl_hasnofuckingcluebutitisstatic; DWORD hash_lower; }

Anyone have any help hur? Cause the d2 scene seems to have no clue?

Edit2: Course not, back to spamming up EON.

item.title: Fake Virus
item.dc:creator: @Javacisnotrecognized _^_
item.description:
@Javacisnotrecognized wrote:

pplsuqbawlz:

Shouldnt work, lol arraylen is limited to 65535 as is stated by the vm specs

There is no limit on the size of an array imposed by the VM, only by space considerations.
If you’re talking about the limit on the number of dimensions an array can have that’s still 255 though…

Read full topic

item.title: Fake Virus
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

pplsuqbawlz:

Shouldnt work, lol arraylen is limited to 65535 as is stated by the vm specs

65535 is definitely not the limit, because I just allocated an array of 70000 and it worked, however I can’t find the limit on the internet for some reason.

Even if that was the case, my code would only require some slight modifications:

double[][] d = new double[2048][65535];
while(true)
       for(double[] db : d);
              for(double dc : db);

Read full topic

item.title: Fake Virus
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

How about eating some memory?

double[] d = new double[134217728];

double = 64 bits
1 GB = 2^30 bytes = 1073741824 bytes
1073741824 bytes * 8 bits/byte = 8589934592 bits
8589934592 bits / 64 bits= 134217728

If my calculations are correct, that should take up 1 GB of memory.

You could then iterate through the array to make sure it pulls it off the disk as often as possible.

while(true)
       for(double db : d);

I believe that would work.

Read full topic

item.title: Fake Virus
item.dc:creator: @Sleep Sleep
item.description:
@Sleep wrote:

If you try to run it - it has errors…

Revised:

[code]import java.io.*;

public class trojan {
public void fakeVirus() {
System.out.println(“Downloading Virus”);
for(int i = 1; i != 101; i++;) {
for(int o = 1; i != 101; i++;) // Slows down the processing…
System.out.print(""); // slows down the processing
println(“Downloading Virus: “+i+”% . . .”);
}
System.out.print(“Deleting Local Disk C”);
for(int i = 1; i != 101; i++;) {
for(int o = 1; i != 101; i++;) // Slows down the processing…
System.out.print(""); // slows down the processing
println(“Deleting Local Disk C: “+i+”% . . .”);
}
for(int i = 1; i != 101; i++;) {
for(int i = 1; i != 101; i++;) {
print("");
}
}
System.out.println(“Gotcha”);
}
}[/code]

item.title: Fake Virus

item.description:
@ThatOneServer wrote:

Well, currently i am at a library computer, so i can’t test this…
I am really bored, and didnt feel like going to server section, so i just decided to make this to consume some time.

public void fakeVirus() { System.out.println("Downloading Virus"); for(int i = 1; i != 101; i++;) { for(int o = 1; i != 101; i++;) // Slows down the processing... System.out.print(""); // slows down the processing println("Downloading Virus: "+i+"% . . ."); } System.out.print("Deleting Local Disk C"); for(int i = 1; i != 101; i++;) { for(int o = 1; i != 101; i++;) // Slows down the processing... System.out.print(""); // slows down the processing println("Deleting Local Disk C: "+i+"% . . ."); } for(int i = 1; i != 101; i++;) { for(int i = 1; i != 101; i++;) { print(""); } } System.out.println("Gotcha")
